properties.name: Watch & Act
properties.action: Monitor Conditions As They Are Changing
properties.location: the Little Desert National Park and surrounding areas including Lawloit, Kinimakatka, Winiam, Gerang Gerung, Dimboola west of the Wimmera River, Duchembegarra and Nurcoung.
properties.webBody:
This Watch and Act message is being issued for the Little Desert National Park and surrounding areas including Lawloit, Kinimakatka, Winiam, Gerang Gerung, Dimboola west of the Wimmera River, Duchembegarra and Nurcoung..
  • There is a bushfire in the Little Desert National Park that is not yet under control. 
  • The fire is active along the northern edge of the Little Desert National park.  Sections of the fire may travel in a northerly direction towards private properties. 
  • There is also some fire activity along the southern edge that may be generating some smoke. 
  • Smoke from this fire may be experienced in communities north of the Little Desert, including Nhill and Kiata. This may persist for a few days.
  • This Watch and Act replaces the Watch & Act issued at 10:54am 29 January.
This fire is still active and the situation can change at any time. You must monitor conditions and be ready to act.
What you should do: 
  • Monitor changes to the situation. Increased wind speed, change in wind direction, smoke or poor visibility can indicate the situation is changing. 
  • Your nose is an excellent smoke detector. If you can smell smoke, take the necessary precautions to protect your health. You can self-assess the air quality near you using https://www.epa.vic.gov.au/for-community/environmental-information/air-quality/smoke/smoke-your-health.
Leave if the situation changes or you feel unsafe. 
Remember to:
  • Take your pets, medications, mobile phone and charger. 
  • Many people have died trying to leave at the last minute during fires. 
  • Travel to the home of family or friends that are away from the warning area or Horsham.
Impacts in your area:
  • Bushfires can spread quickly and are extremely dangerous.

Road Closures: 
  • The Western Highway is now open. 
  • Various local roads are still closed. Check the VicTraffic website (www.traffic.transport.vic.gov.au) or call 13 11 70 for road closures.

A recovery centre will be open from 9:00am Wednesday 29 January at the Dimboola Library, 101 Lloyd Street, Dimboola. 

A Community Meeting will be held 5:00pm Wednesday 29 January at the  Dimboola Library, 101 Lloyd Street, Dimboola. 

The Little Desert National Park is closed for visitors. 

Take action to reduce your exposure to smoke and protect your health: 
  • Everyone should minimise the time spent in smoky conditions whenever practical to do so.
  • People over 65 years, children 14 years and younger, pregnant women and those with existing heart or lung conditions, should reduce prolonged or heavy physical activity. Where possible (and not under direct threat from fires), also limit the time spent outdoors and when indoors, close windows and doors. If there is a break in smoky conditions, open the windows and air out your home.
  • Anyone with a heart or lung condition should take their medication as prescribed. People with asthma should follow their personal asthma action plan, continue to take preventer medication as prescribed and keep reliever medication on hand.
  • If you or anyone in your care is worried about symptoms, seek medical advice or call Nurse on Call on 1300 60 60 24.
  • Anyone experiencing difficulty breathing or tightness in the chest should seek urgent medical assistance and call Triple Zero (000).  
This message was issued by Forest Fire Management Victoria.

The next update is expected by 30/01/2025 11:10 am or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au 
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226 
  • VicEmergency app 
  • Facebook or Twitter (#VicFires) 
  • ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • For information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.   
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service for assistance and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.
properties.text:
WATCH & ACT - BUSHFIRE - Monitor Conditions As They Are Changing
Incident Location: Little Desert National Park
Issue Date: Wednesday 29 January 2025, 05:18 pm
Next Update: Thursday 30 January 2025, 11:10 am

More details at http://emergency.vic.gov.au/respond/#!/warning/36054/moreinfo

This Watch and Act message is being issued for the Little Desert National Park and surrounding areas including Lawloit, Kinimakatka, Winiam, Gerang Gerung, Dimboola west of the Wimmera River, Duchembegarra and Nurcoung..
- There is a bushfire in the Little Desert National Park that is not yet under control. 
- The fire is active along the northern edge of the Little Desert National park.  Sections of the fire may travel in a northerly direction towards private properties. 
- There is also some fire activity along the southern edge that may be generating some smoke. 
- Smoke from this fire may be experienced in communities north of the Little Desert, including Nhill and Kiata. This may persist for a few days.
- This Watch and Act replaces the Watch & Act issued at 10:54am 29 January.


This fire is still active and the situation can change at any time. You must monitor conditions and be ready to act.

properties.name: Advice
properties.webBody:
This Advice message is being issued for Christmas Hills.
  • This Advice replaces the Advice issued at 10:08pm Wednesday 29 January.
  • The bushfire at School Lane, Christmas Hills is under control.
There is currently no threat to communities, but you should continue to stay informed and monitor conditions.
What you should do: 
  • Monitor weather conditions and warnings. 
  • Review your fire survival plan. 
  • If you do not have a plan, decide what you will do if the situation changes.
Impacts in your area: 
  • Emergency services will remain in the area. 
  • Smoke may be visible from nearby communities and roads.
This message was issued by Country Fire Authority.

The next update is expected by 30/01/2025 06:00 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#VicFires)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Watch & Act
properties.action: Monitor Conditions As They Are Changing
properties.webBody:
This Watch and Act message is being issued for Brimpaen, Wartook, Zumsteins.
  • There is a bushfire at Brimpaen, Wartook, Zumsteins that is not yet under control. 
  •  The bushfire has crossed Asses Ears Road and is travelling in a northerly direction towards Rosebrook Glenisla Road. 
  •  Fire crews continue to work to contain the fire spread.
  • The Henty Highway remains closed between Horsham and Cavendish
The situation can change at any time. You must monitor conditions and be ready to act.
What you should do: 
  • Monitor changes to the situation. Increased wind speed, change in wind direction, smoke or poor visibility can indicate the situation is changing. 
  • Enact your fire survival plan. 
  • If you do not have a plan, decide what you will do if the situation changes. 
  • If you have time, check your neighbours to see if they are monitoring conditions. 
  • Protect yourself and your family.
Leave if the situation changes or you feel unsafe. 
Remember to:
  • Take your pets, medications, mobile phone and charger. 
  • Many people have died trying to leave at the last minute during fires. 
  • Travel to the home of family or friends that are away from the warning area.
Bushfires can spread quickly and can start spot fires large distances ahead of the main fire. 
Check the VicTraffic website (www.traffic.transport.vic.gov.au) or call 13 11 70 for road closures.

Grampians National Park visitor and day walks are partially re-opened 
  • The Pinnacle, Venus Baths, Chatauqua Peak and Clematis Falls
This message was issued by Forest Fire Management Victoria.

The next update is expected by 30/01/2025 12:00 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au 
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226 
  • VicEmergency app 
  • Facebook or Twitter (#VicFires) 
  • ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • For information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.   
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service for assistance and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Advice
properties.location: areas of the Grampians National Park affected by the Yarram Gap Road fire.
properties.webBody:
This Advice message is being issued for areas of the Grampians National Park affected by the Yarram Gap Road fire.
  • The status of the bushfire on the eastern side of the Grampians National Park between Bellfield and Bornes Hill is now Under Control.
  • This Advice message replaces the Advice message issued 21 January.
  • Firefighters and heavy machinery continue to monitor hotspots, treat hazardous trees, clear tracks and rehabilitate control lines.
  • Small areas of smoke within the containment area may be visible.
Park Closure:
The Grampians National Park is closed to visitors, however Halls Gap township and the Grampians Tourist Road from Halls Gap to Dunkeld are both open. 

For details on access to the park, visit the Parks Vic website or call in to Brambuk - The National Park and Cultural Centre in Halls Gap.
There is currently no threat to you, but you should stay informed and plan for what you will do if the situation changes. 
What you should do: 
  • Monitor weather conditions and warnings. 
  • Drive with caution. Obey road closure signs.  
  • Visitors are reminded to be cautious of ongoing risks and changes to the environment which may include fallen or damaged trees, smoke and injured wildlife.
  • If you see impacted wildlife - call 1300 356 682. 
Recovery and resilience
If you have been or may be impacted by bushfire, it is understandable if you are feeling concerned and experiencing a mix of strong mental, emotional or physical reactions right now. For emergency relief information during major incidents, call the VicEmergency hotline on 1800 226 226 or visit www.emergency.vic.gov.au/relief
Impacts in your area: 
  • Drivers may encounter fire crews and heavy machinery on roads and tracks. Please take care and drive safely. 
  • Many roads within the fire affected area remain closed. Check the VicTaffic website or call 13 11 70 for road closures.
This message was issued by Forest Fire Management Victoria.

The next update is expected by 04/02/2025 03:20 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#VicFires)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.
properties.text: ADVICE - BUSHFIRE - Stay Informed Incident Location: Grampians National Park Issue Date: Tuesday 28 January 2025, 03:10 pm Next Update: Tuesday 04 February 2025, 03:20 pm More details at http://emergency.vic.gov.au/respond/#!/warning/36001/moreinfo This Advice message is being issued for areas of the Grampians National Park affected by the Yarram Gap Road fire. - The status of the bushfire on the eastern side of the Grampians National Park between Bellfield and Bornes Hill is now Under Control. - This Advice message replaces the Advice message issued 21 January. - Firefighters and heavy machinery continue to monitor hotspots, treat hazardous trees, clear tracks and rehabilitate control lines. - Small areas of smoke within the containment area may be visible. Park Closure: The Grampians National Park is closed to visitors, however Halls Gap township and the Grampians Tourist Road from Halls Gap to Dunkeld are both open. For details on access to the park, visit the Parks Vic website or call in to Brambuk - The National Park and Cultural Centre in Halls Gap. There is currently no threat to you, but you should stay informed and plan for what you will do if the situation changes.

properties.name: Community Information
properties.location: areas north of the Grampians National park.
properties.webBody:
This Community Information message is being issued for areas north of the Grampians National park..
  • Smoke from fires and burning out operations in the Grampians National Park is drifting northerly over a large area including Horsham, Laharum, Wartook, Stawell, and other communities.
  • This is likely to persist until Friday. 
  • Smoke can travel long distances and may be experienced in a much larger area than indicated by this message. 
There is no immediate threat to the community and no action is required.
What you should do:

  • Your nose is an excellent smoke detector. If you can smell smoke, take the necessary precautions to protect your health. You can self-assess the air quality near you using https://www.epa.vic.gov.au/for-community/environmental-information/air-quality/smoke/smoke-your-health.
Take action to reduce your exposure to smoke and protect your health: 
  • Everyone should minimise the time spent in smoky conditions whenever practical to do so.
  • People over 65 years, children 14 years and younger, pregnant women and those with existing heart or lung conditions, should reduce prolonged or heavy physical activity. Where possible (and not under direct threat from fires), also limit the time spent outdoors and when indoors, close windows and doors. If there is a break in smoky conditions, open the windows and air out your home.
  • Anyone with a heart or lung condition should take their medication as prescribed. People with asthma should follow their personal asthma action plan, continue to take preventer medication as prescribed and keep reliever medication on hand.
  • If you or anyone in your care is worried about symptoms, seek medical advice or call Nurse on Call on 1300 60 60 24.
  • Anyone experiencing difficulty breathing or tightness in the chest should seek urgent medical assistance and call Triple Zero (000).
This message was issued by Forest Fire Management Victoria.

Unless the situation changes, this will be the last smoke message issued.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.  
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact the National Relay Service and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Watch & Act
properties.webBody:
This Watch and Act message is being issued for Mona Park, Strachans, Victoria Valley.

  • The bushfire at Grampians National Park - Victoria Range  is not yet under control. 
  • There has been a significant increase in fire activity on the western edge overnight, causing the fire to spread in multiple directions, increasing its size.
  • The fire is still expected to impact private land on the western edge at various points between Hoffmans Rd and Woohlpooer Rd.
  • The north west edge of the fire has crossed Billywing Track and is heading towards the Henty Highway. 
Don't wait, leaving now is the safest option - conditions may change and get worse very quickly. Emergency services may not be able to help you if you decide to stay. 
What you should do: 
  • Monitor changes to the situation. Increased wind speed, change in wind direction, smoke or poor visibility can indicate the situation is changing.
  • Protect yourself and your family. 
  • If you are away from home, do not return.
If the situation changes or you feel unsafe you should leave:
  • Take your pets, medications, mobile phone and charger.
  • Many people have died trying to leave at the last minute during fires. 
  • Travel to the home of family or friends that are away from the warning area or Cavendish. 
Impacts in your area: 
  • The Henty Highway has now been closed between Cavendish and Horsham.
  • Check the VicTraffic website (www.traffic.transport.vic.gov.au) or call 13 11 70 for road closures..
  • Your nose is an excellent smoke detector. If you can smell smoke, take the necessary precautions to protect your health. You can self-assess the air quality near you using the EPA website.
Take action to reduce your exposure to smoke and protect your health: 
  • Everyone should minimise the time spent in smoky conditions whenever practical to do so.
  • People over 65 years, children 14 years and younger, pregnant women and those with existing heart or lung conditions, should reduce prolonged or heavy physical activity. Where possible (and not under direct threat from fires), also limit the time spent outdoors and when indoors, close windows and doors. If there is a break in smoky conditions, open the windows and air out your home.
  • Anyone with a heart or lung condition should take their medication as prescribed. People with asthma should follow their personal asthma action plan, continue to take preventer medication as prescribed and keep reliever medication on hand.
  • If you or anyone in your care is worried about symptoms, seek medical advice or call Nurse on Call on 1300 60 60 24.Anyone experiencing difficulty breathing or tightness in the chest should seek urgent medical assistance and call Triple Zero (000).
This message was issued by Forest Fire Management Victoria.

The next update is expected by 30/01/2025 01:10 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfires)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service for assistance and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

More details at http://emergency.vic.gov.au/respond/#!/warning/36073/moreinfo

This Watch and Act message is being issued for Mona Park, Strachans, Victoria Valley.

- The bushfire at Grampians National Park - Victoria Range  is not yet under control. 
- There has been a significant increase in fire activity on the western edge overnight, causing the fire to spread in multiple directions, increasing its size.
- The fire is still expected to impact private land on the western edge at various points between Hoffmans Rd and Woohlpooer Rd.
- The north west edge of the fire has crossed Billywing Track and is heading towards the Henty Highway. 


Don't wait, leaving now is the safest option - conditions may change and get worse very quickly. Emergency services may not be able to help you if you decide to stay.

properties.name: Advice
properties.webBody:
This Advice message is being issued for Cheltenham, Highett, Moorabbin, Moorabbin East.
  • There is a factory fire in Chesterfield Road, Cheltenham, near the intersection of Keys Road.
  • Smoke will be visible from nearby roads and communities. 
There is currently no threat to the community, but you should continue to stay informed and monitor conditions.
What you should do: 
  • Keep the roads clear so emergency services can respond. 
  • If you are sensitive to smoke or you live with someone who is sensitive to smoke, you should close windows and doors. Turn off heating and cooling systems.
  • To prevent the smell of smoke entering your home or business, close windows and doors.  
Impacts in your area: 
  • The following roads are closed: Chesterfield Road and Keys Road will be closed.
  • Traffic in the area may be affected.
This message was issued by Fire Rescue Victoria.

The next update is expected by 30/01/2025 11:50 am or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 

  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfires)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact the National Relay Service and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

ADVICE - STRUCTURE FIRE - Stay Informed
Incident Location: Chesterville Rd, Cheltenham

properties.name: Emergency Warning
properties.webBody:
This Emergency Warning is being issued for Glenisla, Mooralla, Rocklands, Woohlpooer. 
  • The bushfire 18Km Ne Cavendish is not yet under control. 
  • There was a significant increase in fire activity overnight that caused the fire to spread in multiple directions.
  • The fire activity has temporarily subsided but is still expected to impact private land on the western edge at various points between Hoffmans Rd and Woohlpooer Rd in the next hour.
  • The north west edge of the fire has crossed Billywing Track and is heading north west towards the Henty Highway.  

Leaving immediately is the safest option, before conditions become too dangerous. 

Emergency services may not be able to help you if you decide to stay.
What you should do: 

Travel to: 
  • The home of family or friends that is away from the warning area.
  • The Henty Highway is closed from Cavendish to Horsham
  • You should leave using roads heading in a westerly direction.
  • When you leave remember to take your pets, medications, mobile phone and charger.
In the car: 
  • If you are travelling, do not enter the area. Make a u-turn and travel to safety.
  • Slow down and turn on your headlights. Smoke will make it difficult to see.
If you are unable to leave you should shelter indoors:
  • Close all exterior doors, windows and vents. Turn off cooling systems.
  • You must take shelter before the fire arrives. The extreme heat is likely to kill you well before the flames reach you.
  • Shelter in a room that has two exits, such as a door or window including one directly to the outside. It is important to be able to see outside so you know what is happening with the fire. 
  • If your home catches on fire and the conditions inside become unbearable, you need to get out and go to an area that has already been burnt. 
If you cannot get indoors, other last resort options include:
  • Shelter in the middle of a large open area like a ploughed paddock, football oval or sporting reserve.
  • Get into a large body of water like a dam, lake, river, the ocean or inground pool.
  • Try to protect yourself from the fire's heat.
If you are caught in fire in your car:
  • Park behind a solid structure to block the fire's heat or pull over to cleared area.
  • Try to position the car towards the approaching fire.
  • Turn on your hazard lights and headlights.
  • Close all windows.
  • Turn off the air-conditioning and shut all the air vents.
  • Turn your car engine off.
  • Get down as low as possible below window level and cover up with a pure woollen blanket.
  • Check the VicTraffic website (www.traffic.transport.vic.gov.au) or call 13 11 70 for road closures.
  • Community meetings are being held on Thursday 30th January, 2025 in the following areas:                                                                                                 12.00pm at the Halls Gap Town Hall, 117-119 Grampians Rd, HALLS GAP           7.00pm at the Cavendish Soldiers Memorial Hall,  2 Barker St, CAVENDISH
This messages was issued by Forest Fire Management Victoria.

The next update is expected by 30/01/2025 01:40 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226.
  • VicEmergency app 
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfires).
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service for assistance and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.
properties.text:
EMERGENCY WARNING - BUSHFIRE - Leave Immediately
Incident Location: 18Km Ne Cavendish
Issue Date: Thursday 30 January 2025, 07:37 am
Next Update: Thursday 30 January 2025, 01:40 pm

More details at http://emergency.vic.gov.au/respond/#!/warning/36075/moreinfo

This Emergency Warning is being issued for Glenisla, Mooralla, Rocklands, Woohlpooer. 
- The bushfire 18Km Ne Cavendish is not yet under control. 
- There was a significant increase in fire activity overnight that caused the fire to spread in multiple directions.
- The fire activity has temporarily subsided but is still expected to impact private land on the western edge at various points between Hoffmans Rd and Woohlpooer Rd in the next hour.
- The north west edge of the fire has crossed Billywing Track and is heading north west towards the Henty Highway.  



Leaving immediately is the safest option, before conditions become too dangerous. 

Emergency services may not be able to help you if you decide to stay.

properties.name: Advice
properties.location: North and east of the Little Desert National Park
properties.webBody:
This Advice message is being issued for North and east of the Little Desert National Park
  • There is a bushfire in the Little Desert National Park that is not yet under control.
  • Fire crews have stopped the fire spread and continue work to strengthen containment lines
  • Active fire will be visible from within containments for a number of days. 
  • Crews will be conducting burning out operations on the southern end of the Little Desert during the day. This will generate significant smoke.
  • The northern edge of the Little Desert National Park fire is being patrolled constantly with crews on hand.
  • The potential for this to impact private properties has been reduced
  • Smoke from this fire may be experienced in communities north of the Little Desert, including Nhill and Kiata. This may persist for a few days.  
  • Local communities will see more smoke and ash.
  • There is currently no threat to communities, but you should continue to stay informed and monitor conditions. 
What you should do: 
  • Monitor weather conditions and warnings. 
  • Review your fire survival plan. 
  • If you do not have a plan, decide what you will do if the situation changes.
  • Keep the roads clear so emergency services can respond.
  • Your nose is an excellent smoke detector. If you can smell smoke, take the necessary precautions to protect your health. You can self-assess the air quality near you using the EPA website.
Impacts in your area: 
  • Only residents and those with authorised access are able to enter the Dimboola township. 
Road Closures: 
  • The Western Highway is now open.
  • Various local roads remain closed. Check the VicTraffic website (www.traffic.transport.vic.gov.au) or call 13 11 70 for road closures.

A recovery centre will be open from 9:00am Wednesday 29 January at the Dimboola Library, 101 Lloyd Street, Dimboola. 


The Little Desert National Park is closed for visitors. 
Take action to reduce your exposure to smoke and protect your health: 
  • Everyone should minimise the time spent in smoky conditions whenever practical to do so.
  • People over 65 years, children 14 years and younger, pregnant women and those with existing heart or lung conditions, should reduce prolonged or heavy physical activity. Where possible (and not under direct threat from fires), also limit the time spent outdoors and when indoors, close windows and doors. If there is a break in smoky conditions, open the windows and air out your home.
  • Anyone with a heart or lung condition should take their medication as prescribed. People with asthma should follow their personal asthma action plan, continue to take preventer medication as prescribed and keep reliever medication on hand.
  • If you or anyone in your care is worried about symptoms, seek medical advice or call Nurse on Call on 1300 60 60 24.
  • Anyone experiencing difficulty breathing or tightness in the chest should seek urgent medical assistance and call Triple Zero (000).
This message was issued by Forest Fire Management Victoria.

The next update is expected by 30/01/2025 04:20 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#VicFires)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

ADVICE - BUSHFIRE - Stay Informed
Incident Location: Little Desert National Park
Issue Date: Thursday 30 January 2025, 08:10 am
Next Update: Thursday 30 January 2025, 04:20 pm

More details at http://emergency.vic.gov.au/respond/#!/warning/36076/moreinfo

This Advice message is being issued for North and east of the Little Desert National Park
- There is a bushfire in the Little Desert National Park that is not yet under control.
- Fire crews have stopped the fire spread and continue work to strengthen containment lines
- Active fire will be visible from within containments for a number of days. 
- Crews will be conducting burning out operations on the southern end of the Little Desert during the day. This will generate significant smoke.
- The northern edge of the Little Desert National Park fire is being patrolled constantly with crews on hand.
- The potential for this to impact private properties has been reduced
- Smoke from this fire may be experienced in communities north of the Little Desert, including Nhill and Kiata. This may persist for a few days.  


- Local communities will see more smoke and ash.
- There is currently no threat to communities, but you should continue to stay informed and monitor conditions.
